details.name: DNA Methylation
details.description: Changes in DNA methylation patterns that can serve as biomarkers for metastatic potential of circulating tumor cells (CTCs) and colorectal cancer.
details.findings: DNA methylation data obtained with EPIC array in this study are publicly available at the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository with the Accession Number GSE220096. Metastatic potential of CTCs and colorectal cancer can be assessed through DNA methylation patterns.

details.name: IgG
details.description: A type of antibody that provides long-term protection against infections.
details.findings: Nephelometric methods are sensitive to glycosylation and may yield erroneous results when glycan structures interfere with antibody binding.

details.name: Albumin
details.description: A protein made by the liver that helps keep fluid in the bloodstream.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Transferrin
details.description: A protein that transports iron through the blood to the liver, spleen and bone marrow.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Haptoglobin
details.description: A protein that binds to free hemoglobin to prevent iron loss and kidney damage.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Alpha-1-antitrypsin
details.description: A protein that protects the lungs and liver from damage caused by other proteins.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.description: A protein that helps to carry other substances through the bloodstream.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Alpha-2-macroglobulin
details.description: A protein that can inhibit proteases and bind to certain cytokines and growth factors.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Complement C3
details.description: A protein that plays a central role in the complement system and helps to fight infections.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.description: A protein that plays a role in the complement system and helps to fight infections.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: C-reactive protein (CRP)
details.description: A protein that is produced by the liver in response to inflammation.
details.notes: Not explicitly mentioned but commonly measured in serum.

details.name: Glycans
details.description: Complex carbohydrates that are attached to proteins or lipids.
details.findings: Nephelometric methods may yield erroneous results when glycan structures interfere with antibody binding. Future research will focus on the characterisation of glycan NMR profiles of individual serum glycoproteins, considering variable glycosylation profiles.

details.name: miR-126
details.description: A microRNA involved in regulating carcinogenic physiological behaviors including tumor progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results of diagnosis and prognosis. Part of the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Detectable in blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-1290
details.description: A microRNA involved in regulating carcinogenic physiological behaviors including tumor progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results of diagnosis and prognosis. Part of the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Detectable in blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-23a
details.description: A microRNA involved in regulating carcinogenic physiological behaviors including tumor progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results of diagnosis and prognosis. Part of the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Detectable in blood samples (serum).

details.name: miR-940
details.description: A microRNA involved in regulating carcinogenic physiological behaviors including tumor progression and angiogenesis.
details.findings: Reported as a potential biomarker with robust predictive results of diagnosis and prognosis. Part of the CEx-miRNAs panel for early CRC stages.
details.notes: Detectable in blood samples (serum).

details.name: MSI-H
details.description: Microsatellite Instability High
details.findings: Confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through ICI, offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.

details.name: RAS
details.description: Rat Sarcoma Viral Oncogene Homolog
details.findings: Predictive of the response to targeted agents.

details.name: BRAF V600E
details.description: V-raf Murine Sarcoma Viral Oncogene Homolog B1 (BRAF) with V600E mutation
details.findings: Negative prognostic value but predictive of the response to combined targeted BRAF/EGFR inhibition, doubling survival over standard treatments.

details.name: MSI status
details.description: Microsatellite Instability Status
details.findings: Confers substantial improvements in clinical outcomes and decreased toxicities through ICI, offering patients long-term survival or near curative results.

details.name: MSI
details.description: Microsatellite Instability

details.name: Caspase-3
details.description: A protease that plays a key role in apoptosis.
details.findings: The article mentions the use of Caspase-3 as a biomarker for apoptosis in cancer research.

details.name: Ki-67
details.description: A nuclear protein associated with cell proliferation.
details.findings: The article discusses Ki-67 as a marker for cell proliferation in cancer studies.

details.name: Caspase-8
details.description: An initiator caspase involved in the extrinsic apoptotic pathway.
details.findings: The article mentions Caspase-8 as a biomarker for extrinsic apoptosis in cancer research.

details.name: Ribosomal Protein S6 (RP-S6)
details.description: A component of the 40S ribosomal subunit involved in protein synthesis.
details.findings: The article discusses RP-S6 as a biomarker for protein synthesis and cell growth in cancer studies.

details.name: IFN-γ
details.description: Interferon gamma is a cytokine critical for innate and adaptive immunity against viral, some bacterial and protozoal infections.
details.findings: Increased levels of IFN-γ were observed in patients treated with GCC CAR T cells.

knowledge.object: patients treated with GCC CAR T cells

details.name: TNF-α
details.description: Tumor necrosis factor alpha is a cytokine involved in systemic inflammation and is a member of the tumor necrosis factor family.
details.findings: Elevated levels of TNF-α were detected in patients post GCC CAR T cell therapy.

knowledge.object: patients post GCC CAR T cell therapy

details.name: IL-2
details.description: Interleukin 2 is a type of cytokine signaling molecule in the immune system. It regulates the activities of white blood cells responsible for immunity.
details.findings: IL-2 levels were significantly higher in patients who responded to GCC CAR T cell treatment compared to non-responders.

knowledge.object: patients who responded to GCC CAR T cell treatment

details.name: IL-6
details.description: Interleukin 6 is an interleukin that acts as both a pro-inflammatory cytokine and an anti-inflammatory myokine.
details.findings: Patients experienced a spike in IL-6 levels shortly after receiving GCC CAR T cell infusion.

knowledge.object: patients shortly after receiving GCC CAR T cell infusion

details.name: GCC
details.description: Guanylate cyclase-C is a transmembrane receptor protein that catalyzes the conversion of GTP to cGMP.
details.findings: GCC expression was confirmed in colorectal cancer tissues using immunohistochemistry. GCC CAR T cells showed specific binding and cytotoxicity against GCC-positive tumor cells.

details.name: hCRISPRs
details.description: Human CRISPR-associated sequences involved in transcription and diagnostics.
details.findings: The article discusses the detection and validation of hCRISPRs in transcription and their potential role in diagnostics.

details.name: Acetone
details.description: A chemical compound with a fruity odor
details.findings: Acetone is produced during activities such as exercising or fasting. It is not recommended as a sole biomarker due to its variability.

knowledge.predicate: not recommended as a sole biomarker due to

details.name: 2-Propanol
details.description: A simple alcohol with potential as a cancer biomarker

details.name: 4-Heptanone
details.description: A chemical compound with unclear origins as a biomarker
details.findings: The origin of 4-heptanone is unclear, and it is not recommended for use as a biomarker.

knowledge.object: not recommended for use as a biomarker

details.name: Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs)
details.description: A group of fatty acids produced by gut microbiota

details.name: Hexanal
details.description: An aldehyde with potential as a cancer biomarker

details.name: Microbiome Data
details.description: Data related to the microbial composition in the gut.
details.findings: The article mentions that publicly available datasets of microbiome data were analyzed. The study used Explainable AI (XAI) for analyzing microbiome data in colorectal cancer (CRC).
details.notes: The datasets are available in the Zenodo repository and via a GitHub link.

details.name: Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs)
details.description: Chemical compounds that are emitted from the breath and can be used to detect diseases such as colorectal cancer.
details.findings: The VOCs identified in the study were different from those reported in previous studies. These differences may be explained by the diversity of the mass-spectrometry devices, sample collection process, samples origin (breath, blood, urine or faeces) and geographical differences.

knowledge.object: diversity of mass-spectrometry devices, sample collection process, samples origin and geographical differences

details.name: Alkenes
details.description: A class of hydrocarbons with at least one double bond between two carbon atoms.
details.notes: Main mechanism affecting emission is oxidative stress, which balances formation and scavenging of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and free radicals. Unmetabolized hydrocarbons are excreted in breath due to low solubility in blood.

details.name: Alcohols
details.description: Organic compounds with a hydroxyl functional group attached to a saturated carbon atom.
details.notes: Originate from food and alcohol beverages, also derived from the metabolism of hydrocarbons by cytochrome p450 enzymes.

details.name: Ketones
details.description: Organic compounds with a carbonyl group bonded to two carbon atoms.
details.notes: Acetone is related to ketones, secondary product of lipid peroxidation and predictor for ketosis under high oxidation rate of fatty acids.

knowledge.object: ketosis under high oxidation rate of fatty acids

details.name: Esters
details.description: Chemical compounds derived from carboxylic acid where the hydroxyl group is replaced by an alkoxy group.
details.notes: Found in large amounts in natural sources such as fats, fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers. Further chemical analysis needed to understand elevation and decrease of different VOCs in CRC patients.

knowledge.object: natural sources such as fats, fatty oils, waxes, and fruit ethers
understanding VOCs elevation and decrease in CRC patients

details.name: T-antigen
details.description: A cancer-associated glycan with immature signatures seen in more aggressive lesions.
details.findings: The stools from more aggressive lesions may exhibit abnormal immature glycan signatures not seen in healthy tissues. T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms are potential biomarkers for non-invasive cancer diagnostics.
details.notes: Future efforts should involve screening larger patient cohorts for both the T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms, ideally in multicenter settings. The analysis of patients with negative FIT results is also required to fully disclose the potential of these biomarkers.

details.name: T-expressing glycoproteoforms
details.description: Molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer.
details.findings: Several molecular targets shared by more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer hold promise for future pre-clinical assessment. T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms are potential biomarkers for non-invasive cancer diagnostics.
details.notes: Future efforts should involve screening larger patient cohorts for both the T-antigen and T-expressing glycoproteoforms, ideally in multicenter settings. The analysis of patients with negative FIT results is also required to fully disclose the potential of these biomarkers.

knowledge.object: more aggressive non-cancerous lesions and cancer

mistral-large/KVUjX.prompt_template:
[BEGIN ARTICLE]:<content></content>
[END ARTICLE]

[INSTRUCTIONS]
Generate list of biomarkers that are topic of the article and for each such biomarker extract name, description, type, findings explicitly mentioned in the article, list of knowledge that consist of 'predicate' about the finding from findings and 'object' which biomarker is subject and related via 'predicate'.
Return the response in strict JSON format with the following structure:

[
  { "name": "biomarker name","type":"biomarker type","description":"biomarker description","findings":"findings about biomarker in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of biomarker','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker' }],
  { "name": "biomarker2 name","type":"biomarker2 type","description":"biomarker2 description","findings":"findings about biomarker2 in article","notes":"additional notes important to biomarker2", "knowledge":[{'predicate':'some predicate from findings of  biomarker2','object':'object that relates via predicate to the biomarker2' }] }
] 

Ensure there is no additional explanation, only return valid JSON.
